I think I have seasonal depression. Only just started in the past few years. It was hard to pinpoint why I was getting depressed for a little chunk of the year but it's starting to make sense, I just hate winter. I don't even live in a very cold place, it doesn't snow here, and actually winter weather is objectively nice here.
But I'm starting to hate it now. Like right now it's 7 AM but the sun hasn't even risen yet. I like waking up just as the sun is rising, taking a shower, and then seeing it's nice and bright out by the time I'm ready to start my day.
Ironically, I also am in an improved mood when it's dark out at night. I also hate in the summer when that longest day of the year hits and the sun is still out at 8:30 PM. But that doesn't seem to last as long.
I used to love winter. Cool weather was an improvement to my mood. Now I'm happy maybe one day coming off a hot summer but then it turns depressing in days.
I still like rainy days though, it's so weird.

posts.sub: How do I deal with loneliness and isolation?
posts.com:
It's a long story explaining the events that led to my current situation so I apologise in advance to those who could be bothered to read this.

I was supposed to be on a year abroad as part of a university exchange programme on my course, but roughly 4 months back, about two weeks before I was due to fly off I got caught up in a serious accident that could have killed me. Ended up breaking some bones and I had to withdraw from that year abroad and take a year out from university, meaning I graduate a year later than I should have.

Anyway I've been stuck at home and I'm finally better and can walk, not 100%what I was at before but I'm going to physiotherapy and can get around now. Problem is that I feel completely alone and I'm stuck at home. I can't exactly go out where I want, I've got no car and even if I did where the hell am I supposed to go?

My brother lives and works in another city so I don't see him and my parents are so busy that I hardly see them even when we live under the same roof, feels like there's nobody here but me sometimes. I got to see some school friends for a bit but they'll be going back to other cities/countries when university starts up again. Sometimes I go down to see my university friends but even that is only occasional since I live in Scotland and they're down in London so it's very expensive to travel there and I can only come down for a few days every few months or so.

It wasn't so bad at first but now I'm struggling to deal with it all. I feel so alone and I try to keep myself busy to get my mind off it but there's only so much I feel I can do here? Maybe I'm only here to vent like some idiot but is there anyway I can actually sort this shit feeling out? Sounds dumb but I crave human interaction and company, I'm so starved for it that when I get the opportunity to go out now I'm talking to random strangers as if they're good friends. It's miserable living how I do right now but I don't even know what to do to change it.

The parenting plan allowed for coordinated visits at his discretion. She calls randomly to spend time with him, and my friend doesn't see the harm in it, and lets her have him for the day. She doesn't come back to drop him off that night, and it's the following evening when she finally answers the phone. She said they're half-way to the east coast to live with her dad and that she has brain cancer, then hangs up and my friend isn't able to get ahold of her again for weeks.

During those weeks he filed for a court hearing, hired a better family practice attorney, and is able to have her served summons at her dads on the east coast, only for her to not show up at court here on the west coast. The judge gives her another chance, served again, and she phone's into the courtroom. Judge says bring the kid back , she says no, judge says she'll go to jail if she doesn't for the laundry list of crimes she's committed, Judge asks if my friend can go to the east coast to get his son and he says yes; Judge says she has 3 weeks to comply and give their son to my friend (the legal custody parent) when he goes to get him. Hearing ends.

We do due diligence, call the east coast police where she lives, and come to find out her and her bf filed a restraining order against my friend when they arrived in the east coast, which was awarded. Her police say my friend and any third party acting on his behalf are not allowed there and will be arrested if he or I go there to retrieve the kid; even with a court order from our state; the son's state of residence as described in the Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act. Her sheriff says the same thing, and her state patrol says the same thing. None of them will aid us in the hand-over of my friends son.

Anyone have any advice, resources, or anecdotes to share? Please?

>mine is poorly trained
Train your dog. Especially for a wolf-dog, you need to start getting a few books or, if you think you'll be too sweet/lenient on her, attending obedience classes. Your girlfriend probably doesn't want your dog on the bed for hygiene/space reasons which is reasonable, so give an alternative place for her (the dog, not your girlfriend) to sleep, like a dog bed nearby on your side. As for their relationship, that's going to be a combination of training your dog, giving her a means to expend her energy so she's less aggressive (like more frequent walks), and your girlfriend handling your dog more carefully. You know your dog's likes and dislikes best, but here are a few generic tips to tell your girlfriend anyway:
>At first, avoid touching, talking, or eye contact and separate your dog from your girlfriend
>When approaching, move slowly, in from the side
>Interact only in quiet, calm environments
>Give her a treat or two every so often and only during neutral or positive interacts
>Stay calm, have patience, don't yell, and keep expressions neutral so as not to scare her
As well as that, mediate their interactions. Encourage your dog when she interacts with your girlfriend positively, and gently reprove her if she gets aggressive.

This is total crap.

For an echo chamber to form, everyone in the chamber has to have the same opinion. For a negative echo chamber to form, you have to have a collective of people with similar chips on their shoulders coming together with pre-existing negative opinions.

Echo chambers are far more prevalent irl, the internet is no better at creating them then real life is. What the internet is very good at doing is creating connections between people or groups whom otherwise would never have met. So you get one large echo chamber instead of the multiple smaller ones you would have gotten without the internet.

That can be seen as a good thing because by having them all collected in one place it's less effort to change bullshit ideas.

You do not need the presence of spouses nor of people in relationships to have positive, constructive discussion. What you need is the presence of good will, and healthy mindsets. Failing that, you need leadership from someone with good will and a healthy mindset.

Completely and utterly the opposite of reality. I'm old enough to remember life before the internet as well as the forming of this site. There's something interesting to be learned about human psychology from anonymous imageboards in that even under complete anonymity, group think and hivemind quickly takes hold and creates a specific narrative. In later years this has more obviously been manipulated by bots and attacks to shill specific narratives.
More relevant to the general public is the social media algorithms. Many people get all their news and information from social media websites and streaming sites where the content you click, watch or just take longer to scroll past forms what other content you will see.
Your post reads like the anarchic, idealistic view of the internet of the early 2000s rather than the current ultra-monetized hellscape.

posts.sub: Becoming a hobo.
posts.com:
What equipment should a hobo carry to ensure a peaceful life?

What tips should a hobo be aware of?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Anything that you wouldn’t mind losing or couldn’t be easily replaced. You will be robbed or forced to be separated from everything you own at some point.
A bushcrafter values a sharp knife and uses it for literally everything. You can make knives from knapping but steel is incredibly difficult to replace in the wild. It will also be your guardian angel. Knowing skills such as how to make a shelter with deadfall, twine from plants, fire from friction, etc. will be essential. A few good books and online resources will help, but may be better to learn from someone.
Foraging and identifying plants and mushrooms, trapping and hunting animals, and acquiring natural resources will require lots of study and practice. These are skills that require many years to develop and you may be a helpless little baby until you learn how to sufficiently survive in the wild.
Lastly you may (and probably will) get sick or injured. There’s certain things you can treat yourself such as infections or some poisons. But if you break a bone for instance, you will never recover properly without a doctor. This is an extremely dangerous way to live and may corrupt your body and mind in horrifying ways.

posts.sub: OCD is driving me insane
posts.com:
Hello folks. I was wondering if any of you got advice on how to deal with, or ideally overcome, OCD?
My main issue at the moment is having intrusive thoughts in the from of images of "people" which I find indescribably disgusting. They are the most annoying when I'm working on my computer, because then I get into dilemmas of having to close and reopen windows, overwrite and redownload files or cut and repaste text. All of that happens because while interacting with something I get an intrusive thought and then that said thing starts to feel dirty (because I start to associate it with those filthy images), and so I have to discard it and start from scratch so that I doesn't feel dirty anymore. That gets really annoying really quick (I once had to restart my pc about 60 times in a row due to this). It of course affects a bunch of other stuff in my day to day life besides my computer work, but that is the part of my life which I care most about.
Something that complicates this further is that the urge to do a compulsion gets stronger the more I care about something, because the more I care about something the more I care that that something doesn't become dirty.
It have multiple times felt like I'm at my limit and have ruminated about suicide a lot too. I have tried a bunch of meds but none have made a great difference. And I haven't yet tried therapy because, after analyzing and introspecting myself, I highly doubt that it would be worth it.

I don't think that I can continue to live like this and retain a sane mind for much longer. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28001842
Why do you say therapy wouldn’t be useful? And what type of therapy do you mean? I used Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP). It is not at all like talk therapy - it is more like “Pavlov’s dog” style behavioral conditioning, which should work on almost anyone. Very high success rate for OCD statistically. Regular talk therapy does almost nothing for OCD though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28001887
The disgust, anxiety, etc... is simply too high when I'm forced not to do a compulsion. I feel as if the thoughts are winning if I don't cleanse their influence. I just cannot stomach the feeling of something dear to me getting smudged by that filth. I cannot bring myself to interact with something that I find dirty, my mind would be to focused on remembering that the thing I'm interacting with is dirty and I'd therefore give even more attention to the intrusive thoughts.
I just want to have the memory of them removed from my brain. I don't think that I can live with something so unsettling constantly popping up in my mind.

Another way to tackle compulsions when it feels too difficult is to remember that you aren’t supposed to stop everything at once. Start with the very easiest thing to let go of and just spend a week focused on not doing that. Then move on to the next easiest thing and so on. You don’t have to tackle your most anxiety related compulsions until the very end, when you’ve already proven to yourself how much you’re capable of.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP I'm from a country where people are used to being a lot poorer. Smaller houses, smaller cars, less amenities etc. As a result people consider 'fantastically wealthy' to mean anything more than just getting by. 100k income would absolutely shoot you into that category in the eyes of most here, but in reality it means maybe a nicer car and a nicer house, but it isn't actual wealth, like fuck you money, like renovate a chateau money, like send your children to be privately educated and/or international university money, like retire early money.

That said, because this country isn't so completely fucked in regards to being open for business, relatively free in regards to logistics, imports etc you can still with hard work make a decent amount of money. It is about corrupt enough for you to avoid quite a lot of tax.

That said, 100k is (when not viewed through the lens of globally wealthy) is absolutely enough here to live extremely comfortably and if you are happy with that then why not be happy?

What I did is I played along with it all in my 20's so I could earn comparatively quite a lot of money. I didn't sleep much, I worked and worked as much as my body could take. I bought a modest house at 32 and I'll have paid it off within the next year. I've nowhere near the fantastic levels of potential you've got with your career because of where I am, but after the house is paid off my total yearly outgoings drop to the point where they are covered by 10 hours of work a week at minimum wage which is the freedom I want to make me happy. I've about 5 years income in savings and investments too.

You should totally keep your racket going until your late 30's. Don't live beyond your means, get stuff in place that'll reduce your outgoings over time (suitable property). Work out where your savings are going to be invested and how that looks like. Assess it on an ongoing basis.

>>28004087

Yeah, no. If you're trying to break up with your girlfriend then you don't need to go gaslighting pretending you're not only to do it a few days later.

Get yourself set up to move out, get a place sorted then hire removalists or get some friends to come help and just move everything out in the same day you tell her the relationship is over. Tell her an hour before you start moving things out and let her know people are on their way over to move you out.

In the lead up, don't pretend like everything is ok. Make it clear the relationship isn't going well. The last thing you want when you tell her is a shock. Shock means big outbursts. If she's expecting it, she's less likely to explode. That other people are on their way is likewise more likely to manage the risk of outburst.

>>27999547
Hey, I have BPD so I'm clinically insecure.

I think that the fact your reassured her and explained is great, however, your posts suggest her insecurity is something you struggle to grapple with. That leads me to believe you probably default to explaining how she's wrong to feel the way she feels as a way to fix it, before you have validated her feelings. Regardless of your views on gender issues I think we can all admit that women face a disproportionate amount of pressure to be beautiful and to also meet their partners needs for sexual novelty, we are trained to constantly feel in competition. Clearly she has reasons for viewing your ex as a threat that go beyond you, I know it's stressful because that insecurity is being directed at you but if you really want to stay with this girl then being the guy who sits and listens to her talk about all the challenges she's faced in trying to feel "good enough" for others you could help her see that the issue is bigger than your ex liking Instagram posts. Until you make her feel safe by not being afraid of her human emotions, she may not feel calm enough to have that self awareness. Right now she is in panic mode.

There are loads of articles online about validating emotions, the big thing is to give feedback that shows you understand her feelings and that they're valid and you love this part of her too.

These are skills all relationships benefit from but we aren't taught how to communicate in that way. If you struggle with identifying other people's emotions use pic related and then ask her "so you're feeling x emotion?" this could open a wider conversation about how you can support her to work through overwhelming feelings like that.

Some time apart for the dust to settle could be good for you both too.

>>27999806
I obviously cannot say that she had BPD from the information provided, but it is common for families to not recognise one person has a disorder or traits, because another family member has the same issues but with much higher support needs.

My symptoms displayed similarly to your gf until I was in a relationship with someone who loved me unconditionally. Breaking up with someone before they can break up with you is a common manifestation of splitting. If you give her space to calm down she may reach out to you. It's better you let her decide than for her to feel you've talked her into staying because she's likely unsure of her own judgement.

The best thing you can do to keep things healthy with someone like ur gf, is to be predictable by keeping strong boundaries, being aware of your own needs and setting clear expectations. It is much better for you to keep expectations low and exceed them than to disappoint. This is because any evidence that can be interpreted in a negative manner, will be.

You have to look out for yourself too, I mean, you're probably really drained and pushed to your limits right now. That's why you're asking for advice on 4chan, right?

If you stay together, something important would be to discuss boundaries in the relationship for both of you, including stuff to do with social media and cheating. In the future maybe you could suggest that she check out resources on handling overwhelming emotions (the DBT handbook is good but there are also resources online) and maybe consider some therapy. Make it clear that this is something you are suggesting not because she's a burden to you but because you cannot take away her self hatred no matter how hard you love her, but that because you love her it hurts to see her suffer.

Don't forget to look after yourself, anon. This kind of relationship can be rewarding but you need to be committed to making sensible decisions even when your partner can't for it to work.

>>28001786

Marriage -
The most basic husband-wife setup is incredibly nice when it works. Most faggots on here will screech that she will cheat/fuck the dog or whatever retarded shit they are spewing this month. For me, I dated for nearly a decade to make sure she wasnt crazy, good fit, got career setup. She cooks, cleans, and fucks. Having someone who will take care of you, pay 1/2 of the bills, and just generally be there is amazing. I can still generally do whatever I want, but I have always made an effort to moderate all parts of my life. Balancing vidja, with wife, with hobbies, with work is key. Dating and marriage have been the exact same for me, and I highly recommend it if you can find right girl.

Children -
They are great. They are expensive as fuck. US seems to want everyone to be childless. I want to have a second, but I seriously dont see how its possible to afford another if I want to get bigger house/ private school/ college/ vacations/ etc. I have a very good job, but I have no idea how anyone affords this. It sucks because having a kid is amazing. As with above, the shrieking incels really undersell how great it is for a toddler to waddle over to you and tell you that you are their favorite. In crass terms, I compared my pictures of my dog with my kid over a 1 year period. I had x4 of my kid. So clearly, a kid is x4 of a good dog. As a parent, I see childless friends are lesser in my eyes now. They are missing something.

Freedom -
Its retarded to think family limits freedom. Economics limits freedom. Having a family is a choice that I have made, and my success has made it possible. If you think being a NEET/ loner wageslave makes you “freerer” I have bad news for you; you will live an unfulfilling life. Choosing not to have a family is something that I can respect. Falling into it because you couldnt find a gf/wife and turn that into a family is a fundamental failure on your part.

>>28003285
Best parts are that I actually enjoy my family. Also, they keep me from going off the deep end. I have a natural self-destructive streak, and honestly think I would be dead by now if I didn't have my kids.

The down sides are having to keep 4 other people in mind with every decision I make. I occasionally get a hair up my ass and want to move to a cabin in the woods far from society, but that's not an option with my kids. Also, most of my income goes to taking care of everyone else. I usually don't think about it, but sometimes it would be nice to just buy myself something stupid and expensive, and it's just usually not an option. And yeah, it would be fun to go out partying and fucking random women, but I honestly do prefer what I have. Oh, and children can be a real pain in the ass sometimes. They, by far, require more work and effort and attention than anything else you'll ever deal with. It can be exhausting, and infuriating at times.

My kids are 13 and 14, and I adopted my niece 6 years ago, she's now 18. My wife is 41 and I'm 39. Been together for 16 years now. Things with my wife are good. We're together largely because I like her more than anyone else I know, so I try to keep her around.

The rest of my family is dead, so not much of a relationship with any of them. We used to get help from my wife's mom and sister, but they've moved away, which isn't a big deal considering my kids are pretty much self sufficient at this point. It's basically just us at this point.

I go out with my friends I've had since highschool once or twice a month. We do a bunch of pretty normal stuff. Go eat, play games, watch fights. Whatever fun thing we can come up with.

Regrets... Are hard to say. Like I said I like my kids, and changing things would mean I wouldn't end up with them. But realistically I should have waited to have them. Things were rough the first few years because my wife and I weren't really ready, and they almost destroyed our relationship.

>>28003753
They were 8 or 9. Again, pretty self sufficient. They still need you to make sure they don't kill themselves, or burn down the house, but they can handle the basics on their own.

With my wife, we fought over everything. We were ill prepared financially and emotionally. She was pretty miserable when she was pregnant, and had a really rough time with postpartum depression. We we living in a town I hated, working a job that was killing me. Combined with the stress of a newborn, and we were both pretty on edge. She rushed back to work sooner than she probably should have, but we were struggling on a single income. We took a lot of it out on each other. At one point she moved out and went to live with her sister.

We basically had to learn to be in a relationship all over again. We had to learn to communicate, and what it meant to be parents together. People can tell you how tough having kids is, but you really won't understand until it happens. It changes everything, and you're basically trying to figure out an entirely new way of life. It's not necessarily bad; it's just a lot of change all at once.

Having kids is overwhelming. There isn't really a way to avoid it. Preparation will make stuff easier, but it's never easy. You just have to accept it.

>or whatever you still want sex positivity. You still want married people to be having good sex.
The treatment isn't worth the side effects. Good sex within marriage doesn't require cultural permissiveness towards sexuality in general, and that permissiveness does far more to undermine the meaning of marriage than public taboos on sex possibly could.
This is even more the case if you're talking about acting on porn-induced fetishes and wild sexual fantasies, which have no place whatsoever in a healthy marriage.

>of sex being this dirty, shameful thing that even married people weren't supposed to talk about.
This is a gross oversimplification at best and a downright lie spread by "sex positive" hedonists at worst. While you can find plenty of people who misunderstand things at any point in history (e.x. the fucktarded Victorian men who visited prostitutes so they wouldn't "defile" their wives), when the moral teachings of the past are looked at, sex itself was and is not the issue. Its treatment was. Sex outside of monogamous marriage was wrong. Publicly, yes, it was something you didn't talk about in polite company, because what purpose would that serve other than to lower people's inhibitions towards sex in general? You don't need to talk about it with anyone BUT your spouse or a doctor in the vast majority of conceivable cases.

Iirc, there was one famous island in Ireland which was known even in Victorian times as being maximally repressed. And still, it was reported that none of the islanders ever had any trouble 'figuring things out' once they got married. If even they got by in their situation, you're overstating the case for how much the current climate would actually help.

You might be able to make an argument that *maximal* repression isn't the best way to handle things, but if we're talking about how to strengthen traditional marriage, the best course of action definitely isn't an "everything goes" mentality.

>Alrighty then, what's a well-adjusted and/or emotionally intelligent guy look like?
That's a pretty broad question that will really depend on age but a well-adjusted, emotionally intelligent person is typically someone who has a semblance of what a working relationship is supposed to look like - meaning that they have experience with people and know what kinds of behaviors, sacrifices and accommodations are required in order to maintain a meaningful bond with another human being. A lot of this is learned through practice which is why I say most of these qualities are absent in teens. They know how to be emotionally vulnerable and how to accept someone's emotional vulnerability. They have a reasonable ability to introspect and to process their own emotions before acting on whatever whim they're struck with - meaning something might make them angry or depressed or jealous but they have the ability to pause, examine these feelings and process where they're coming from and why. They have enough experience and mental wherewithal to notice things like social cues, body language and to generally interpret the very basics of what people are thinking or feeling. They have a semi-developed sense of self - meaning that they generally know who they are, what they want and are not using relationships to fill some emotional void or deficiency. I could go on but these are the basics.

>What the fuck is a "social circle?"
A group of people who you speak to and interact with in real life. Not on a discord, not on XBOX, not on snapchat.

I'm sorry for what you're going through anon, maybe you could find some friends via this thread? You don't deserve to go through all this alone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28003637
Most anxiety can managed with internal reasoning. How you respond to things is a choice, and you create neural pathways in the brain that make it easier to respond the same way the next time. This becomes a habit.

I suggest therapy, but most people ignore it and want to DIY their mental health. You absolutely can, but it's dumb and most people fail. Therapists are studied professionals.

However:

So just start deciding not to get worked up. Start looking at your body, feel what it feels like to be anxious over something, start examining the physical aspects of these negative emotions. Now start trying to reverse them. Breathing exercises work. You can create a physical baseline that your body will respond to and return. You have to PRACTICE these decisions and PRACTICE these responses and PRACTICE your breathing.


Once you have the physical aspects understood, start examining the thoughts. Why continue to dwell on things you can't change? The future is happening all the time everyday you're moving forward and things are happening to you. Why allow your self to dwell on negative shit?

It also helps to do psychedelics. Acid and morning glory seeds helped me manage my anxiety and depressed issues. Of course it's because my issues were mental, due to my abusive and tumultuousupbringing, not chemical imbalances.

Relationships with sharp disparities (age, wealth, sexual experience, background) break down much more often than those between compatible people with similar traits. That's not to say that transactional relationships can't eventual work out and become something more meaningful, it's just that they tend to fail when time passes and the law of diminishing marginal utility erodes the main reason for the relationship.

>> How do you explain this?

Pussy isn't an achievement, least of all in this environment. Why do you imagine thinking about it should have any positive impact on mood or mental state?

Depression is not feeling sad, you can't just think of something good in your life and stop feeling depressed. Depression is your brain churning over a problem or trauma it's stuck on as you prepare for personal growth. Who you are mentally on the other side of depression is different than who you are before it.

Think of depression as a chrysalis stage in your journey through life. Sometimes depression has external factors such as trauma, but usually it comes from within.

Physical exercise creates endorphins which temporarily alter your neurochemistry so you feel a little bit better. That's normal, it's why therapists have long suggested exercise as part of overcoming depression periods. Be sure to use those times practically to think through stuff as they'll allow you to be more rational during that period.

Have you considered therapy?

Do you lift? How frequently do you interact socially? Do you have skills or achievements? Have you ever helped people and do people rely on you or look up to you? I speak from some personal experience as well as from theorizing, I think confidence comes mostly from experience but also from how one views oneself.

P.S. Maybe if you care about something enough, you can use that motivation to overcome any social anxiety you had about the situation beforehand. For example, you'll be a lot more willing to engage in conversation about something you know something about and then that experience can allow you to get more confident about social situations in general and then specifically situations like this.
